Detailed Description

This subclass of QT's QVariant class represents the data types that are defined in XML-RPC. It handles serialization to and from XML using QDOM. Users of the library should probably NEVER use this class. It is used exclusively by XRMethodCall and XRMethodResponse.

See also:
http://www.xmlrpc.com/spec
The clean mapping between QT types is the following. A key feature is that is REVERSIBLE, i.e. it is one-to-one. All deserialization is done according to the clean mapping.
  • C++ int : XML-RPC int
  • C++ bool : XML-RPC boolean
  • C++ double : XML-RPC double
  • QT QString : XML-RPC string
  • QT QDateTime : XML-RPC dateTime.iso8601
  • QT QByteArray : XML-RPC base64
  • QT QList<QVariant> : XML-RPC array
  • QT QMap<QString,QVariant> : XML-RPC struct
The lossy mapping is the above plus the following:
  • C++ uint : XML-RPC int
  • QT QDate : XML-RPC dateTime.iso8601 with time 00:00:00
  • QT QStringList : XML-RPC array
  • All others, if they can be cast to QString : XML-RPC string
  • All others, to empty strings.
Note that the lossy mapping is NOT reversible. You will have to use QVariant::cast() to convert it back to it's original type, and you will not know what the original type was without extra information.

Use the static method XRVariant::isXmlRpcType() to check to see if you can cleanly map. If you do not check before hand, a lossy mapping may occur. The responsibility to make sure that data can be cleanly mapped is on users of the library. The library will always make a best-effort, which may be lossy.

bool XRVariant::isXmlRpcType (  const QVariant &    qv )  [static]
 

If this is a map or list type, it recurses through all the elements and checks all of them.

Returns:
true if qv is not one of the lossy types
